snippet: The use of police force against minorities and whites alike is poorly tracked, but what data does exist suggests the number of law-enforcement homicides have risen only slowly, if at all.
abstract: Data suggests that rate of police killings has risen only slightly since 2009, or not at all, despite public impression that phenomenon has accelerated following death of Michael Brown in 2014; authoritative data on use of lethal force by police is lacking nationwide, but analysis shows it is in fact an old and steady problem, and that apparent uptick is likely due to increased awareness from cell phone videos.

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES and SARAH COHEN

lead_paragraph: The use of police force against minorities and whites alike is poorly tracked, but what data does exist suggests the number of law-enforcement homicides have risen only slowly, if at all.

headline.main: Police Killings Rise Slightly, Though Increased Focus May Suggest Otherwise
headline.print_headline: Police Killings Rising Slightly, Data Suggests
